response.answer_text: The Inca Empire was Successful because of Pachacuti Inca Yupanqui, The Ninth Sapa Inca. Before The Inca Empire was Created, Manco Capac, The First Sapa Inca, Founded The City of Cusco in 1200. Cusco became The Kingdom of Cusco. Cusco was The Capital of The Inca Civilization, until the neighboring Chanka Tribe would attack The Kingdom of Cusco. At The Time, The Eighth Sapa Inca Viracocha Fled in Fear, While One of His Sons Remained and Successfully Defeated The Chanka Tribe. With His Outstanding Military Skill, This Inca became The Ninth Sapa Inca, by The Name of Pachacuti a Inca Yupanqui. Pachacuti means “He Who Overturns Space and Time”, “Earth Shaker”, “He Who Overturns The World”, “Cataclysm”. Pachacuti being Leader lead him Vastly Expanding The Inca Empire, creating Cities, Temples, Roads, and More Terrace Farms. The Inca Empire was The Largest, Only, and The Most Powerful Empire in The Pre-Columbian America’s. The Inca Empire - .Built The Greatest Roads, Comparable to The Roman Empire .Built Terrace Farms .Several Big Cities, Temples, and Administrative Centers .Built The Largest Empire in The Pre-Columbian America’s .Domesticated Llamas, Alpacas, Guinea Pigs, Potatoes, and Corn .Had The Greatest Army, with The Best Strategy, Discipline, Armor, Weaponry, and Size in The Pre-Columbian Americas .Had an Organized and Stable Empire .Were Great Astronomers and Brain Surgeons .Had The Greatest Pre-Columbian Architecture, building Fortresses, Temples, and Cities with Well Fitting Stones so well, you can’t Fit a Piece of Paper in Between. Even Inca Ruins and Buildings in Cusco and Sacsayhuaman Nowadays, you wouldn’t be able to fit a Fingernail in between the Stone Cracks, which is Inca-Redibly Impressive Considering How Long Ago The Inca built these and still Survive Today .Built Cusco on The Andes Mountains and were Able to Adapt in The High Altitude Mountainous Andes. In Fact, Cusco still survives Today in Peru, being a UNESCO World Heritage Site called The City of Cusco. It’s Impressive How Cusco still survives after about 800–900 Years during The Kingdom of Cusco. In, 1450, The Sapa Inca, Pachacuti Inca Yupanqui built The Famous Estate of Machu Picchu. Machu Picchu was Constructed by Pachacuti Inca Yupanqui as a Inca Citadel Estate for Pachacuti. Another Key of Success was how Powerful The Inca Empire was, that They could manage to conquer other Civilizations and Kingdoms to Expand their Empire. The Inca had a Fierce Army, with Strong Troops, so Battles with The Other Kingdoms ended them Successful. The Inca Empire employed central planning. The Inca Empire traded with outside regions, although they did not operate a substantial internal market economy. While axe-monies were used along the northern coast, presumably by the provincial mindaláe trading class, most households in the empire lived in a traditional economy in which households were required to pay taxes, usually in the form of the mit'a corvée labor, and military obligations, though barter (or trueque) was present in some areas. In return, the state provided security, food in times of hardship through the supply of emergency resources, agricultural projects (e.g. aqueducts and terraces) to increase productivity and occasional feasts. The economy rested on the material foundations of the vertical archipelago, a system of ecological complementarity in accessing resources and the cultural foundation of ayni, or reciprocal exchange.
